documents.content: The detective surveyed the scene enthusiastically, taking in all of the surrounding area. He examined each square foot of land as if it was a puzzle, trying to piece together a picture in his mind. Frank Albertson stood nearby, his son Bill at his side. Bill was holding a shotgun he had earlier been sent inside to find, upon discovering their scarecrow. You see, Frank Albertson awoke early in the morning, got into his overalls, and went out into his fields. But when he arrived, he found his scarecrow and much of the surrounding produce in ruin. At first he thought the crows had been wise to his scheme, and that they had torn the scarecrow apart. But when he found the scarecrow's head, and its straw for brains scattered nearly twenty yards away from where its body lay ravaged, he concluded that the offender was a bigger, stronger creature. “I don't think it was an animal,” muttered Detective Johnson, now examining the scarecrow's torso. “These slashes are too clean to be from an animal. This was done with a knife -- one with a wide blade. The cuts run deep, and yet it doesn’t look like any fabric was torn. So it was done with more of a stabbing motion, I'd say.” “Someone stabbed my scarecrow?” Frank grimaced, raising an eyebrow. “And look at this,” the detective continued. He reached into the straw-lined body of the scarecrow, and pulled out a sunflower seed. “Do you grow any sunflowers on your farm, Mr. Albertson?” “’Fraid not” he answered briskly. “Can you tell me the names of any nearby people? Perhaps any rival farmers?” “Well,” he answered, “there is Professor Surenie. He’s a schoolteacher. He doesn't farm himself, but his boy has been looking into the business. He might have done something.” “Anyone else?” the detective asked. “Bill, could you give us a few minutes?” he asked, turning to his son. Bill glared at his father and walked away. “As to your question, detective. Yes, there are other people I have in mind. There’s Rachel Beaton, the wife of a wheat farmer. Or Mr. Fletcher, a grocery store owner who was recently hurt financially by some rotten vegetables I sent in. … And, there’s my son.” “You suspect Bill?” “Bill and I had a bit of a tiff last night,” the farmer explained, removing his cap momentarily and scratching his nearly hairless scalp. “Wouldn't surprise me if he took it out on me.” “What was the fight about?” “He was upset about losing something he’d just bought. I may have been a bit hard on him … telling him that he’s irresponsible and that he loses everything. … It started there at least.” As Frank spoke, the detective came upon a footprint. He took a picture, and then slid the sleek digital camera back into his pocket. The detective called the town's police station, and managed to convince the police chief to dispatch a car to round up the three other suspects. An hour later, they were there, lined up, awaiting the detective's word. “One of you,” he said, “is responsible for this mess. And I want to know who.” The grocery store owner, Mr. Fletcher, replied in a hostile manner, “I've been at my store all day, and was doing inventory all night. Couldn't have been me,” he said, spitting a seed on the ground. The detective nodded, then looked at Professor Surenie, the next in line. “I was out of town until morning -- at a teacher's conference in Denver.” Once more, the detective nodded. Next, he looked at Rachel. “I was … err … indisposed last night.” Bill interrupted: “She was passed out at the bar -- I passed there when I was in town, picking up a new hunting knife.” This triggered the detective's interest. “And where is that knife now, boy?” he asked. “I don't know,” he answered. “I must have lost it when I was in town.” “How convenient,” the detective noted. He stepped towards the footprint he found earlier, lining it up with his own boot. It was the same size as his shoe -- size 11. He got his camera, and took another snapshot of the print, but this time with his foot on it. After this, the detective turned to Frank Albertson. “Sir, when did you say you sent in that shipment of rotten vegetables to Mr. Fletcher?” “About two months ago,” he answered. “Why do you ask?” The detective ignored him, and went on to ask Bill a question. “Bill, you say you lost your recently purchased hunting knife. Is this correct?” Bill nodded. “Where, might I ask, did you go while in town after purchasing it?” “Once I got it, I went to the grocery store, and then after picking up some food for my dad, I came right home.” “Uh-huh, I see,” said the detective. Suddenly, he clapped his hands together, and addressed the suspects. “All of you may go home tonight. I will call for you to return to this farm tomorrow afternoon. Then I will give you my findings.” The next day, they all dutifully returned, looking a bit nervous. When they were settled down in the Albertson living room, the suspects looked at one another curiously. “If you would all be so kind, I ask that you would each take off one of your shoes,” said the detective. The four suspects complied. After they had each taken off a shoe, he compared each one to his own boot. All of the men’s shoes were about the same size, while Rachel’s was a good deal smaller. “Now, just to remind you all … unlike a scarecrow, I have a brain and the capacity to think. And I think I know who our offender is.”

original_metadata.reveal_text:
“Who did this on my farm?” Frank frowned.
“Well, Bill claims he lost the knife he bought just last night,” Detective Johnson replied. Normally, I wouldn’t believe him, but you relayed earlier that Bill was upset last night over losing something. That something was the knife. The final place Bill went to was the grocery store -- this is likely to be where Bill lost the knife.”
“Then who had the knife?” asked Rachel.
“Well, we know you didn’t have it. Your shoe is not big enough to match this footprint. And we know that the professor was out of town. I may not be able to prove that Mr. Fletcher took the knife from the grocery store, where Bill left it. But I can prove that Mr. Fletcher likes sunflower seeds.”
Mr. Fletcher, no longer able to keep up with this charade, suddenly broke out into tears. “It's not my fault!” he yelled. “Frank deserves it! He cost me profits!”
“It was an accident!” Frank explained. “I sent a truck to deliver them, but it got stuck some miles up the road from the store. It went rancid before he could get them to him.”
“Liar! You wanted to ruin my business!” Mr. Fletcher yelled.
“Mr. Fletcher, regardless, I am afraid I am going to have to take you in.” The detective handcuffed Mr. Fletcher, took him to his car, and drove him down to the police station. “Mr. Fletcher,” the detective said looking back, “try not to drop your sunflower seeds next time.”
The grocery store owner sighed, spitting out another sunflower seed toward the scattered scarecrow.

detection.solution:
<THOUGHT PROCESS>
1. 	Motive 
    •	Mr. Fletcher – angry at Frank for having delivered a load of vegetables that spoiled and cost him money.  
    •	Bill Albertson – furious with his father after the quarrel the previous evening in which Frank called him “irresponsible” for losing a brand-new purchase.  
    •	Rachel Beaton – no clear reason to hate Frank; the story gives her no motive.  
    •	Professor Surenie – likewise no motive except a very remote “his boy may go into farming”.

2. 	Opportunity / Alibis  
    •	Rachel was “passed out at the bar” – if true, she was physically incapable.  A bartender would easily confirm that.  
    •	Professor Surenie was at a teachers’ conference in Denver.  A hundred witnesses and hotel bills can confirm that.  
    •	Mr. Fletcher was supposedly doing an overnight inventory inside his own store, but nobody corroborates it and nothing keeps him from locking the door and driving to the Albertson farm.  
    •	Bill was in town, bought a new hunting knife, stopped at the grocery store, then came home.  No one saw him after he left town.  He certainly had access to the farm all night.

3. 	Physical evidence  
    •	The weapon: a “wide-bladed” knife used with a stabbing motion.  Bill had just bought a hunting knife and, according to his father, was already upset about “losing” it that same night – far too convenient.  
    •	The footprint: men’s size 11, a size that fits Bill, Fletcher and the detective himself.  It eliminates only Rachel.  
    •	The sunflower seed inside the scare-crow:  
         –  Frank grows no sunflowers.  
         –  Bill had just come from the grocery store where sunflower seeds are sold and may even have bought some as part of the “food for Dad.”  
         –  A single seed ended up deep inside the straw body.  Dropping a seed from one’s mouth while spitting (Fletcher’s habit) would hardly drive it through burlap and straw; the seed is much more likely to have been stuck to the blade or fallen out of a pocket while the wielder’s hands were inside the scare-crow.  

4. 	Logical deduction  
    •	The only person certainly possessing the right knife during the relevant hours is Bill.  
    •	The quarrel with his father gives him a strong, immediate emotional motive to “teach Dad a lesson.”  
    •	Bill had unrestricted access to the field in the middle of the night.  Fletcher would have had to make a special trip, risk being seen, and work in unfamiliar darkness – all merely on the chance of damaging some crops.  
    •	The “I lost my knife in town” explanation is exactly the “irresponsible” behaviour his father had berated him for, making it sound contrived.  
    •	Planting sunflower-seed evidence conveniently points at the one man known to chew and spit seeds – an obvious attempt at misdirection.

Taken together, the evidence fits Bill and only Bill.  The detective arrested the wrong man.
</THOUGHT PROCESS>

<SUSPECTS>
Bill Albertson, Mr. Fletcher, Rachel Beaton, Professor Surenie
</SUSPECTS>

<CULPRIT>
Bill Albertson
</CULPRIT>

<EVENT RECONSTRUCTION>
Bill drove into town in the early evening and bought a new hunting knife.  Still angry about his father’s constant criticism, he brooded on the way home.  At the grocery store he picked up several items his father wanted – including a small sack of salted sunflower seeds to snack on.  
Back at the farm, the resentment boiled over.  He slipped out to the field after dark, took the still-boxed hunting knife, and vented his anger on the nearest symbol of his father’s work – the scare-crow and the surrounding produce.  He stabbed and slashed with the wide blade, ripping the torso open and scattering straw and vegetables.  When he thrust the knife into the scare-crow, one or two sunflower seeds that had stuck to the blade or that were loose in his shirt pocket fell into the empty cavity.  
Finished, he pocketed the knife, returned to the house and hid it, then went to bed.  In the morning, when his father discovered the destruction, Bill pretended to look for a shotgun and later invented the story that he “lost” his knife at the grocery store, hoping any inquiry would drift toward the grocer who is always spitting sunflower-seed shells.
</EVENT RECONSTRUCTION>

<WHY THE OTHER SUSPECTS ARE INNOCENT>
•	Professor Surenie was verifiably in Denver; dozens of colleagues could confirm his presence.  
•	Rachel Beaton was seen unconscious at the bar for most of the night; even if she woke later, the size-11 boot print rules her out.  
•	Mr. Fletcher certainly chews sunflower seeds, but there is no evidence he ever possessed the knife, and a random seed-spitter would not somehow force a seed inside the stuffed torso.  His only connection is an old business grievance that had already cooled for two months; it is insufficient compared with Bill’s fresh anger and ready weapon.  The seed was planted to incriminate him.
</WHY THE OTHER SUSPECTS ARE INNOCENT>

“Who did this on my farm?” Frank frowned.
“Well, Bill claims he lost the knife he bought just last night,” Detective Johnson replied. Normally, I wouldn’t believe him, but you relayed earlier that Bill was upset last night over losing something. That something was the knife. The final place Bill went to was the grocery store -- this is likely to be where Bill lost the knife.”
“Then who had the knife?” asked Rachel.
“Well, we know you didn’t have it. Your shoe is not big enough to match this footprint. And we know that the professor was out of town. I may not be able to prove that Mr. Fletcher took the knife from the grocery store, where Bill left it. But I can prove that Mr. Fletcher likes sunflower seeds.”
Mr. Fletcher, no longer able to keep up with this charade, suddenly broke out into tears. “It's not my fault!” he yelled. “Frank deserves it! He cost me profits!”
“It was an accident!” Frank explained. “I sent a truck to deliver them, but it got stuck some miles up the road from the store. It went rancid before he could get them to him.”
“Liar! You wanted to ruin my business!” Mr. Fletcher yelled.
“Mr. Fletcher, regardless, I am afraid I am going to have to take you in.” The detective handcuffed Mr. Fletcher, took him to his car, and drove him down to the police station. “Mr. Fletcher,” the detective said looking back, “try not to drop your sunflower seeds next time.”
The grocery store owner sighed, spitting out another sunflower seed toward the scattered scarecrow.
